FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION CONTINUES TO BE A CHALLENGE FOR LIMITED-RESOURCE POPULATIONS. ALTHOUGH OHIO, MICHIGAN AND PENNSYLVANIA ARE HOME TO OVER HALF OF THE AMISH POPULATION IN THE US, STATE EDUCUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ARE OFTEN GENERIC AND DON'T ADEQUATELY ADDRESS SPECIFIC NEEDS OF THE AMISH. A STAKEHOLDER ROUNDTABLE MEETING IDENTIFIED THE NEED FOR GAPS TRAINING THAT IS MORE RELEVANT TO FARMING PRACTICES UTILIZED BY PLAIN GROWERS. WHILE MANY PLAIN GROWERS HAVE PARTICIPATED IN GAPS TRAININGS IN THE PAST AND ARE AWARE OF ON-FARM FOOD SAFETY HAZARDS, IT IS EVIDENT THAT PROGRAM CONTENT AND DELIVERY METHODS SHOULD BE MODIFIED TO BETTER MEET THE NEEDS OF PLAIN GROWERS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSALS ARE TO: 1) DEVELOP GAPS TRAINING ADRESSING THE UNIQUE FARMING AND HANDLING PRACTICES AND COMMUNICATION REQUIREMENTS OF PLAIN GROWERS, 2) PILOT PLAIN GROWER GAPS WITH DISTINCT SETTLEMENTS IN OHIO, PENNSYLVANIA AND MICHIGAN (TRI-STATE), AND 3) SHARE MATERIALS WITH PLAIN GROWER POPULATIONS THROUGH NORTH CENTRAL REGION CENTER FOR FSMA TRAINING. PLAIN GROWER GAPS TRAINING WILL BE CULTURALLY ADAPTED, CONSIDER SOCIOLINGUISTIC CHARACTERISTICS AND CONSIST ENTIRELY OF PRACTICES UTILIZED BY PLAIN GROWERS. THE MATERIALS WILL BE DESIGNED FOR SETTINGS WITHOUT ELECTRICITY. USER-FRIENDLY PRESENTATION MATERIALS AND FOOD SAFETY PLAN AND RECORDKEEPING TEMPLATES WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR PLAIN GROWERS. THE TRAINING WILL BE PILOTED BY PLAIN GROWERS ACROSS THE TRI-STATE AND COMPLEMENT ON-GOING FOOD SAFETY TRAININGS IN THESE STATES. COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW US TO REACH A LARGER NUMBER OF PLAIN GROWERS ENSURING A GREATER IMPACT ON FRESH PRODUCE SAFETY IN THE TRI-STATE REGION.

FRUITS, VEGETABLES, AND FSMA COMPLIANCE: MULTILINGUAL AUDIOVISUAL FOOD SAFETY TRAINING FOR FARMS AND PACKINGHOUSESSINCE ALL FRUITS AND VEGETABLES ARE AT RISK OF CONTAMINATION DURING GROWING, HARVESTING, AND PACKING WITH MICROORGANISMS THAT CAN MAKE PEOPLE SICK, IT IS IMPORTANT FOR EVERYONE WHO WORKS WITH FRESH PRODUCE TO ACTIVELY WORK TO REDUCE RISKS. SINCE MOST FRESH PRODUCE IS EITHER HAND HARVESTED OR HAND PACKED, FOCUSING ON WORKER TRAINING IS A WISE INVESTMENT FOR FARM AND PACKINGHOUSE OWNERS. EVEN IF INDIVIDUAL FARMS AND PACKINGHOUSES ARE NOT DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN A PRODUCE-ASSOCIATED FOODBORNE ILLNESS OUTBREAK, IT IMPACTS THE PRODUCTION, MARKETING, AVAILABILITY, AND SALES OF FRESH PRODUCE AS WELL AS CONSUMPTION RATES. SINCE THE CONSUMPTION OF FRESH PRODUCE HAS SO MANY POSITIVE EFFECTS ON HEALTH (E.G., MAINTAINING A HEALTHY WEIGHT, REDUCTION IN CANCER RISKS, REDUCTION IN HEART DISEASE RISKS), IT IS CRITICAL TO BOTH INDIVIDUALS AND THAT NATION THAT FRESH PRODUCE BE SAFE, AVAILABLE AND AFFORDABLE. ENSURING THAT THE PRODUCE INDUSTRY HAS THE TOOLS TO TRAIN THEIR WORKERS IN ORDER TO REACH THE GOAL OF REDUCING FOOD SAFETY RISKS IS AN IMPORTANT TASK.THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT TRAINING NEEDS FOR PRODUCE FARM AND PACKINGHOUSE OWNERS AND WORKERS THROUGH THE PRODUCTION OF MULTILINGUAL EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS FOR FOOD SAFETY TRAINING OF WORKERS. AUDIO-VISUAL COMMUNICATION OF INFORMATION IS EXTREMELY USEFUL FOR KNOWLEDGE RETENTION AND HELPS TO OVERCOME CHALLENGES RELATED TO LOW LITERACY. IN ADDITION, TRANSLATIONS ALLOW WORKERS TO EXPERIENCE TRAINING IN A LANGUAGE THEY UNDERSTAND WITH APPROPRIATE VERBAL EMPHASIS. THE VIDEO FORMAT ENSURES STANDARDIZED TRAINING IN PLACES WHERE ACCESS TO QUALIFIED FOOD SAFETY TRAINING MAY BE INACCESSIBLE OR UNAFFORDABLE FOR GROWERS, PACKERS, FARM WORKERS AND THEIR SUPERVISORS. IN 2004, CORNELL UNIVERSITY PRODUCED A FARM WORKER HEALTH AND HYGIENE TRAINING VIDEO FOR THE NATIONAL GOOD AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES (GAPS) PROGRAM. IN THE THIRTEEN YEARS SINCE ITS RELEASE, MORE THAN 14,500 COPIES HAVE BEEN DISTRIBUTED NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY. IN 2011, THE FOOD SAFETY MODERNIZATION ACT (FSMA) WAS SIGNED INTO LAW AND INITIATED THE FIRST EVER REGULATION FOR FRUIT AND VEGETABLE PRODUCTION. THE FINAL VERSION OF THE FSMA PRODUCE SAFETY RULE RELEASED ON NOVEMBER 27, 2016 INCLUDED NEW WORKER TRAINING REQUIREMENTS, SO GROWERS, PACKERS, AND FARM WORKERS ARE IN NEED OF UPDATED WORKER TRAINING EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS.
NATIONAL DAIRY FOOD SAFETY PLAN COACHING WORKSHOP

THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE BURDEN OF FOODBORNE DISEASE ATTRIBUTED TO ON-FARM CONTAMINATION OF FRESH STRAWBERRIES. AS AN INTERMEDIATE STEP TO ACHIEVING THIS GOAL, WE WILL DEVELOP A NOVEL FOOD SAFETY OUTREACH 'ADD-ON' CURRICULA. THE AIM OF THIS ADD-ON CURRICULUM IS TO FACILITATE INTEGRATION OF THE FOOD SAFETY MODERNIZATION ACT (FSMA) PRODUCE SAFETY RULE AMONG VERY SMALL AND SMALL-SIZED STRAWBERRY GROWERS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. TO INFORM DEVELOPMENT OF THE CURRICULUM, WE WILL FIRST CONDUCT ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS OF PARTICIPATING FARMS IN ARKANSAS TO IDENTIFY GAPS IN PRACTICES OF VERY SMALL AND SMALL-SIZED STRAWBERRY GROWERS. THIS APPROACH WILL ALLOW US TO CUSTOMIZE THE TRAINING MATERIALS SO WE DELIVER CONTENT SPECIFIC TO THESE GROWERS NEEDS. THE THREE OBJECTIVES TO ACHIEVE OUR AIM ARE:1. CONDUCT SURVEYS AND INTERVIEWS WITH VERY SMALL TO SMALL-SIZED STRAWBERRY GROWERS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES.2. CONDUCT ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS ON VERY SMALL TO SMALL-SIZED STRAWBERRY FARMS IN ARKANSAS.3. DEVELOP AND EVALUATE THE ADD-ON CURRICULUM DELIVERED TO VERY SMALL TO SMALL-SIZED STRAWBERRY GROWERS IN ARKANSAS.THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS RELEVANT TO THE GOALS OF THE AFRI FOOD SAFETY OUTREACH PROGRAM AS THE PRIMARY FOCUS IS TO ENHANCE COMPLIANCE OF THE PRODUCE SAFETY RULE BY DEVELOPING CUSTOMIZED, COMMODITY-SPECIFIC ADD-ON TRAINING THAT CAN BE USED AS A MODEL FOR DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE ADD-ONS SPECIFIC TO OTHER UNIQUE FRESH PRODUCE PRODUCTS.
PRACTICAL TOOLS FOR FOOD SAFETY ON SMALL, DIVERSIFIED FRUIT & VEGETABLE FARMS

ALABAMA A&M UNIVERSITY (AAMU) SMALL FARMS RESEARCH CENTER IS COLLABORATING WITH THE ALABAMA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SYSTEM (AUBURN AND ALABAMA A&M UNIVERSITIES),TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY, AND FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY TO DELIVER PRODUCE SAFETY AND GAP TRAINING TO SPECIALTY CROPS GROWERS IN ELEVEN COUNTIES COVERING ALABAMA, GEORGIA AND TENNESSEE. ON-FARM PRODUCE SAFETY AND QUALITY IS AN ISSUE OF GROWING IMPORTANCE TO STRENGTHENING ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF SMALL-SCALE FARMS AND COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES, AS WELL AS IMPROVING OVERALL PUBLIC HEALTH. DEMAND FOR LOCALLY-GROWN FRUITS AND VEGETABLES CONTINUES TO SURGE, AND ALONG WITH THAT, BUYER REQUIREMENTS CONTINUE TO GET STRICTER. INTEREST IN INITIATIVES SUCH AS FARM TO SCHOOL AND FOOD HUBS CONTINUES TO GROW, WHICH IS VERY POSITIVE, BUT FARMERS MAY NOT ALWAYS BE PREPARED TO MEET THE FOOD SAFETY AND QUALITY REQUIREMENTS OF THESE MARKETS. SOME OF THESE MARKETS REQUIRE GOOD AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES (GAP) CERTIFICATION, WHICH REQUIRES EXTENSIVE DOCUMENTATION OF THE SAFETY OF THEIR PRODUCE. THE U.S. FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION (FDA) FOOD SAFETY MODERNIZATION ACT (FSMA) PRODUCE SAFETY RULE (PSR) IS NOW FINAL, AND COMPLIANCE DATES FOR SOME FARMS BEGUN ONE YEAR AFTER THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF THE FINAL RULE. THIS IS THE FIRST TIME THAT PRODUCE GROWERS HAVE HAD GOVERNMENT FOOD SAFETY REGULATIONS IMPOSED ON THEM. THE PSR, FOR THE FIRST TIME, SCIENCE-BASED MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR THE SAFE GROWING, HARVESTING, PACKING, AND HOLDING OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES GROWN FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION. UNDER FSMA-PSR, ALL FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN PARTICIPANTS MUST COMPLY, WHERE APPLICABLE. FRESH PRODUCE CAN BECOME CONTAMINATED FROM CONTACT WITH SOIL; MANURE; IMPROPERLY COMPOSTED MANURE; IRRIGATION WATER; FECAL MATERIAL FROM WILD AND DOMESTIC ANIMALS; FARM, TERMINAL MARKET WORKERS; CONTAMINATED EQUIPMENT, PACKINGHOUSE AND DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM; WASH RINSE AND FLUME WATER; ICE; COOLING EQUIPMENT AND TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES; CROSS-CONTAMINATION FROM OTHER FOODS; AND IMPROPER STORAGE, PACKAGING, AND PREPARATION. FARM OWNERS AND WORKERS HAVE INTIMATE CONTACT WITH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES AS THEY HARVEST, SORT AND PACK THESE FOODS. WORKER HEALTH AND HYGIENE THEREFORE ARE A MATTER OF CONCERN, ESPECIALLY FOR COMMODITIES THAT REQUIRE EXTENSIVE MANIPULATION AND HANDLING DURING HARVESTING, PACKING AND PROCESSING. THUS, FDA FSMA IMPACTS MANYASPECTS OF A FARM OPERATION AND REQUIRES ADDITIONAL RESOURCES FOR TRAINING, RECORD-KEEPING, PRODUCT INFORMATION AND TRACEABILITY SYSTEMS, AUDITORS, AND FOOD SAFETY AND LEGAL STAFF. FSMA ALSO TAKES CORPORATE LIABILITY TO A NEW LEVEL BY HOLDING FOOD SAFETY EXECUTIVES ACCOUNTABLE. MANY RETAILERS, RESTAURANTS AND INSTITUTIONS IN METRO AREAS - BIRMINGHAM, HUNTSVILLE, MOBILE, MONTGOMERY, ATLANTA, SAVANNAH, NASHVILLE, CHATTANOOGA, MEMPHIS AND KNOXVILLE - WANT TO PURCHASE LOCAL PRODUCE; HOWEVER, THEIR FOOD SAFETY PLANS AND POLICIES INCREASINGLY REQUIRE THAT THEIR SUPPLIERS BE GAP CERTIFIED OR HAVE SOME KIND OF THIRD PARTY FOOD SAFETY AUDIT. CURRENTLY, ONLY A VERY SMALL PROPORTION OF THE SPECIALTY CROP GROWERS IN THE REGION HAVE GAP CERTIFICATION. NOT HAVING GAP CERTIFICATION IS THEREFORE A LARGE AND GROWING BARRIER, AND HENCE AN OPPORTUNITY, FOR INCREASING THE SALES OF SPECIALTY CROPS. THE PROJECT'S LONG-TERM GOAL IS TO INCREASE PRODUCE SALES AND PROFITABILITY OF SPECIALTY CROPS BY PROVIDING GAP TRAINING AND FSMA EDUCATION, RESOURCES, SUPPORT, AND ONGOING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO GROWERS.. THE RATIONALE IS THAT PREPARING LIMITED-RESOURCE SPECIALTY CROP GROWERS WITH THE FOUNDATIONAL PRINCIPLES OF PRODUCE SAFETY, FOOD SAFETY LIABILITY RISKS AND MANAGEMENT SKILLS, WILL HELP THEM MAKE BETTER FOOD SAFETY DECISIONS AND COMPLY WITH FSMA. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT AT LEAST 825 GROWERS AND REACH OVER 3,500 GROWERS, CONSISTING OF SMALL DIVERSIFIED FRUITS/VEGETABLE OPERATIONS; AND IT BUILDS CAPACITY AND BREAKS DOWN FOOD OR PRODUCE SAFETY BARRIERS FOR GROWERS, AND ALSO BY ENGAGING IN EFFECTIVE COLLABORATION TO CREATE AND IMPLEMENT MARKETING AND PRODUCE SAFETY PLANS AND CAMPAIGN AS WELL AS DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS.
